def: The way a business arranges itself to carry out its activities
A plan showing the roles and relationships between all the employees in a business
An employees immediate superior or boss
The power to control others and to make decisions
The number of employees managed directly by another employee
The layers of authority within a business
The line of authority within a business along which communication passes
The removal of one or more levels of hierarchy from a business organisation structure
The passing down of authority to more junior employees
The exchange of information between two or more people
Where employees working in all areas of the business can take decisions
Where a small number of senior managers in a business take all the important decisions
When a business starts selling new products in new markets
This is the proportion of a workforce who remain with the business over a period of time; usually a year.
The process of finding and appointing new employees.
This is where a business chooses the right employees from those that have applied for a job.
Where a job vacancy is filled from within the existing workforce.
Filling a job vacancy from any suitable person not already employeed by the business.
The collection and interpretation of information about a job.
This states information about the duties and tasks that make up a job.
This sets out the qualifications and skills required by an employee to fill a job
This document gives information about a person including qualifications - employment history and interests
The quantity of goods or services produced by an employee over a period of time; such as a year.
The extent to which customers requirements are met.
The part of a business that is concerned with meeting customer needs as fully as possible.
A legal document stating the hours of work - rates of pay - duties and other conditions under which a person is employed.
When employee works a number of hours equal to the normal working week. Usually somewhere between 35 and 40 hours.
When an employee works for fewer than the normal number of working hours per week.
When two or more employees agree to share the responsibilities of a single job.
Allows employers to hire staff without any guaranteed hours of work.
The range of factors that influence people to behave in certain ways.
Designing a job to give interesting and challenging tasks
The extras that employees may receive in addition to their pay; like a compnay car.
A method of payment under which employees are paid according to the quantity of products they produce.
An hourly rate of pay which is set by the government. All employees above a certain age must receive at least this rate of pay.
A range of activities giving employees job-related skills and knowledge
The training given to an employee when he or she first starts a job
Training given in the workplace
Training provided outside of the place of work
